ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A thorough introduction to all sorts of schools of thought about how and why Americans decide how to turn out to vote, whom we vote for, and align with political parties. After about a month of foundations, we also explored the effects of various specific factors like the impacts of race and the media.
Learned a lot about theories of political behavior in the contemporary American context.

Knowledge: Extensive knowledge about various political science quantitative models of the American electorate, including the role of partisanship, polarization, media, campaigns, gender, race, and more. 

Skills: A deeper understanding of how to read, analyze, write, question, and discuss a social science paper.

Insights: Lots of them, but they'd come across more in discuss form.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength - Prof. Kalla is the best seminar leader Ive ever had. Every week I felt like I left with so many new questions and ideas. 

Weakness - I would have liked more structure (ie intermediate assignments) to force myself not to procrastinate the final paper until reading week. Own goal.

Strengths: randomized call on system kept everyone engaged and forced people to do the readings
Weaknesses: Instructor should ban the use of laptops so as to prevent people (myself included) from disengaging with discussion during the class. I also think having 4 response papers instead of 5 might've been better, though I don't feel super strongly about this.

The strengths are in the organization of the readings and discussions. If you do the readings every week (as you are highly incentivized to do), you learn a ton of new content. As an undergrad, I also thought that getting to discuss with grad students and in a very small seminar allowed for a much higher level of discussion than in many other seminars. I really couldn't say enough good things about this course. As for the weaknesses, it was a lot of reading. That's not a weakness, but just worth considering.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you want a challenging but rewarding poli sci seminar and/or are in the fence about whether grad school is right for you.
Yes, if they're prepared to actually do the readings and contribute to class discussion

I really couldn't recommend highly enough. It is both a large and difficult workload every week if you do the readings, and if you take this course, you better do the readings. You just learn so much content, have such great discussions, Prof. Kalla is amazing, and the final paper gives a chance to think in a big way about a political science question.
